head.title: Elegy IX.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 32-35.

l.emph: Some mute inglorious Milton here may rest.

epigraph.bibl: Gray.22 Thomas Gray, An Elegy wrote in a Country Church Yard (1751), p. 8.

lg.l: Come, Melancholy, sweetly pensive maid,
O lead me to thy haunts, and weeping cells,
Where mimic mirth, nor folly dare invade,
Thy lov’d retreat, where contemplation dwells.
Beneath some aged tree, I’ll lie reclin’d,
Among the lonely mansions of the dead;33 Used in Henry Baker, Medulla Poetarum Romanorum (1737), p. 488, from Nicholas Rowe’s translation of Lucan’s Pharsalia, book II.
To ruminate the fate of human kind,
And from the tombs my future fortune read.
Some lie beneath the marble’s polish’d stone,
With sculpture grav’d and honour’s ensigns hung,
Perhaps distinguished by wealth alone,
And mighty made by flatt’ry’s guilty tongue.
While round them lie a poor inglorious crew,
Whose characters no wand’ring search can trace,
Where no memorial rises to the view,
No sculptur’d stone to tell their resting place.
Say, were they such a poor ignoble race,
Whose memory no monument requires?
Did they in life employ no useful place?
Do nothing which the giddy world admires?
Sure here were hearts with great emotions fir’d,
Though ignorance conceal’d the gen’rous flame
Of such as would to mighty deeds aspir’d,
And stood immortal, in the rolls of fame.
So the rough marble in the quarry lies,
A mass in which no beauty can be seen,
Till the skill’d statu’ry his art applies;

Then smiles a Juno,44 Patron goddess of the Roman Empire and protector and special counselor of the state; daughter of Saturn, sister and wife of Jupiter and mother of Mars and Vulcan. or the Paphian Queen.55 Derived from Pamphos, an ancient city of Cyprus known for its temple to Venus. In his translation of Virgil’s The Aeneid (1693), John Dryden references “the Paphian queen”: “Then, on the top of Eryx, they begin / A rising temple to the Paphian queen” (V.990-991).
Soon shall the mourner, of this artless song,
Sink in the narrow house unknown to fame,
There sleep in silence, with the vulgar throng,
Without the least memorial of his name.
For him, no sable ensign shall be born,
No gorgeous pageants crown the nodding herse,
No monument his humble grave adorn,
Nor Bard record him in immortal verse.
Perhaps the simple swains, who list’ning stray’d
To hear his pipe, at eve amid the bow’rs,
With mournful songs will sooth his pensive shade,
And strew his grave with sweetest vernal flow’rs.
Some gen’rous friend, hung o’er the silent urn,
May shed a tear, and heave the artless sigh;
With unfeign’d grief his luckless fortune mourn,
While pow’r and wealth’s unvarying cheeks are dry.

A sad attendant on her Damon’s77 Virgilian pastoral name found in Eclogue 8. Cf. also Milton, "Epitaphium Damonis" in Poems (1645). bier,
His loss bewail, the soft contagion share,
And pay the welcome tribute of a tear.
